Definition: If you find that the input comment has pornographic materials and activities that offend the public's sense of decency, then classify it as obscene else classify it as non-obscene.

Comment: The suggestion that there is "human waste" spread around The Field is false. I walked every foot of that site in the weeks before the eviction notice – I was one of the volunteers picking up trash. There was no poop or pee to be seen or smelled anywhere, even when we dug into huge piles of trash. The City provided Honey Bucket portable toilets, and the residents used them. 

KC Public Health is being sloppy or disingenuous here. It was filthy, yes, and there were rats, but no poop! That's important, because uncontrolled shit is so disgusting that it prejudices the discussion.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: I agree most of them taste like crap.  But I'm still trying to figure out why eating animals is bad or immoral. I eat animals. I owe it to this cycle to make sure my body is appropriately nourished to continue the cycle.  My body is omnivorous. It is designed to consume both plants and animals.  I am not so egotistical to think that I am above the nature in which I was created.  There is a logic and order to the biological diversity of the planet.  Who am I to screw with it.  So vegans, get off your high horses and quit condemning those of us who like meat as somehow less compassionate and less in tune with nature than those who just eat plants.  I say to them, they are depriving the bugs of a well-fed body. How inconsiderate.

-The sample size in this study allows the authors to come to the conclusion they want to come to in the first place

-The others are forest fires. All were in old growth or reburns of previous fires that did not get salvaged

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down.

Comment: We do love the Church. If we didn't, we would have left years ago. We reject YOUR idea of the Church, but that's something else entirely. 

We think that abandoning "orientation, liturgical language, liturgical music" is a good thing. Having the priest stand with his back to the congregation, mumbling in a language most of the laity do not speak, is a terrible way of having a communal worship service. Religious music is one of the best examples of "Sturgeon's Law" I know of (the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon was told, "Ninety percent of sf is crud", to which he replied "Ninety percent of EVERYTHING is crud".) Yes, today's music also exemplifies Sturgeon's Law.

BTW, Montanism was not condemned solely for having women priests. It was largely condemned for its theological beliefs. Your statement is simplistic at best.

We think about the teachings. If they give us good arguments, we accept them. Crap gets rejected. The arguments against ordaining women are crap, for example.

Comment: Farris' death was entirely avoidable but, tragically, few Counties in Washington State currently follow best practices in housing criminal suspects that have severe mental or emotional health challenges.

The best place to house people like Farris is not in a jail, but in the custodial ward of a hospital, where they can remain in secure custody but under the primary supervision of medical professionals.

If Island County doesn't have the resources to create such a custodial ward for itself then they should combine efforts and resources with neighboring counties to create such a ward for the region that is centrally-located and which they all use and help to manage.

Creating and then sharing the costs and the custodial and medical personnel to staff such a ward is one way Island County and its neighboring counties can avoid unnecessary tragedies like Keaton Farris in the future.

Comment: Future grids structure will likely be different from current grid structure for a number of reasons.  The use of electrochemical storage in the form of batteries like the li-ion will likely be a component of the structure because they can rapidly store and release energy in an efficient manner.
Future grids will likely have large DC component because most storage works best with DC and even long distance high voltage transmission is more efficient with HVCD. There will likely be individual or microgrids, linked to minigrids that will link to the larger grid that at a national level will be able to deliver renewable power very efficiently. Large grid storage can efficiently use hydrogen and it will be the an important choice for long term storage although things like pumped water will always be cost effective as they have been. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_energy_storage_projects

Comment: Faculty regularly have to not only face the economic realities the rest of America see, but also have to deal with a fair bit most people do not have to deal with.  Commonly faculty has to do research as well as teaching, which means they have to come up with a good research topic and find research funding on a regular basis.  It is like having a job, and regularly having to get hired again on a regular basis... while still having the original job.  Also, it is commonly competitive among ones peers, so it can get cut throat among your coworkers for research funding (the coworker you have lunch with could stab you in the back tomorrow just for funding).  If you lose your research funding, or if you do not have a good research project, you could then lose your faculty teaching job.  So it is commonly more complex than regular workers of the rest of America sees.  It is quite a bit harder than you are suggesting.

Comment: Jade: "modesly" is actually an innovative contraction peculiar to discussion of housing patterns, urban demographics and inner-city residential development.  Its etymology is traced to discussion of "more densely" developed urban centers especially in reference to residential units.  In today's usage you might read "modesly" devloped city centers generally promote more affordable urban residential tenancy. Comment: You make great points...  to further; the rates charged by the insurers in Alaska and most states are actuarily determined by an outside company such as Milliman... Those rates then must be submitted to the state for approvals... There must be 'rate adequacy' to ensure the insurance company collects enough money for the expected claims, build a cash reserve, and pay for the operations...  most carriers have administration and claims management costs under 24%... this means that there is 86% in loss holding capacity in which to pay claims... (roughly)... Insurance companies are going broke in the individual insurance markets and in small group markets.. Those are losers now there is no high risk pool...  

You are correct..  You MUST get everyone coverage or allow a hospital to deny access to care without payment.   Medicare (single payer) has cost shifted onto those with insurance... Hosp charge more to those with insurance.  In AK its typically 400% to 600% higher than medicare pays.

Comment: Native allotments held in trust for Native owners  are already Indian Country. Their owners could convey them to tribes but there would be no good reason for them to do this. Instances when Native owners transfer ownership to a tribe usually take place in the Lower 48 where fractionated allotments with many Indian owners lie within the boundaries of existing reservations. That is not the case in Fairbanks.
As to cannabis cultivation, like any other business venture tribes would want to research the market and laws and would then have to develop their own regulations.  Anyone who has followed the development of State and local regulations knows how difficult this is and how expensive it is to get started. Tribes would progress with caution like any other business owner.
We are a PL 280 state; state criminal statutes for cannabis would apply.
There cannot be any "casino business" in Alaska unless the State changes its gambling statutes.

Comment: Light gets bent by gravity.  However, it isn't much, unless you have a huge gravity source, like a quasar.  The earth's gravity can only bend light a tiny amount, the moon even less.  So, the moon's gravity won't bend the sun's light enough to bend around it and get to us.  

Here's why:

http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/10/health/how-to-safely-watch-the-eclipse/index.html

You can look at the eclipse ONLY if it's a total eclipse, and you can only look at it when it's totally eclipsed.  Any other time is dangerous.

Comment: No one said we shouldn't have roads. 
Just that we should prioritize pedestrians, transit, and biking above private cars in funding and design of our public space. 
Currently we prioritize car traffic far above all else, making all other means of getting around extremely difficult. 
Continuing to do this is not sustainable. There is not and will never be enough money and space for everyone to drive. We have to invest our limited transportation funds in modes that are more energy and space efficient, and that are financially sustainable. That means putting money into bike and pedestrian infrastructure. That means not only allowing buses to use the roads, but dedicating them space so that they can function efficiently and actually be useful to people. 

I did not say to build special roads for commercial vehicles. I was placing them within a hierarchy of priorities, and suggesting that the gas tax they pay needs to be raised.

Comment: The Conservative stimulus program was well managed.  As Paul Welles writes in “The Longer I’m Prime Minister”: “the auditor general would even congratulate him on the care he and his officials had taken in ensuring that the proper rules were followed in disbursing the money”. 
I don’t know what surplus you are talking about. There was a $1.9B surplus in 2015-16, and the PBO said there would have been a $2.9B surplus in 2016-17 if Justin “the budget will balance itself” Trudeau hadn’t turned it into a $1B deficit. The $2.1B revenue from the General Motors sale, presumably the one-off sale you are talking about, was in 2015-16, not 2014-15. Even if you deduct the $2.1B from the PBO’s estimate of a $2.9 surplus for 2015-16 you still get a surplus. 
Why do you consider deferring spending a "bogus" way to balance a budget? Isn't deferring optional spending something everyone does to help balance their budgets?

Comment: Sorry, I didn't realize I was hogging the access to Google.
Lee and Jackson were childhood heroes of J. Henry Ferguson, owner of the Colonial Trust Company, who left money in his will for the statue. A shortage of materials for the sculptor during wartime caused a decade's delay in its dedication. On hand that day in 1948 among 3,000 Baltimoreans were the generals' grandchildren, the governor and the mayor, Thomas D'Alesandro Jr., who brought along his 8-year-old daughter. You may know her today as Nancy Pelosi.
The statue was placed in a park across the street from the Baltimore Museum of Art and Johns Hopkins University. Baltimore was below the Mason-Dixon line, but Maryland, a war-torn slave state, never seceded from the Union. (John Wilkes Booth was from Maryland.) A retirement home near Baltimore for Confederate soldiers closed in 1932.
The Union Soldiers and Sailors statue, Baltimore's lone monument to the victorious, is the only one the city paid for and endorsed.

Friends in EU noticed an absence of spiders and moths at front porch lights in recent years. You cant blame that on cats! 

I recommend buying tall bird feeders from Wild Birds on Willamette and 26 with a device to prevent rodents climbing to food.  

US Dept of Interior in 2014 wrote almost 7 million bird deaths a year result from collision with cell towers alone.

Add invisible pollution from cell tower microwave radiation to the scenario and think again before blaming cats!

Comment: There are many other aspects that don't seem to be accounted for in the Frontier Center study:
Why are many dense European cities long surrounded by green belts not experiencing surges in real-estate prices? Could it be that they have more restrictive land tenure or aren't immigration magnets? 
Why do the NA examples of  "successful" cities without containment only exist in Texas where they are heavily subsidized by oil to compensate for their lack of diversified economic opportunities and don't need to be vibrant places to attract investment and immigration?
Conveniently cities with similarly diverse and vibrant cores to Toronto or Vancouver, but lacking greenbelts have been left out of the analysis (New York, Boston). Is it because they are also very expensive? Maybe truly successful cities are desirable regardless of containment?
To create a level playing field, should cities be dumbed down, or should every city be vibrant and densely urban, so that they are all equally valuable?

Comment: The misunderstanding with the current implementation of the homesteading program designed by John Wise and Prince Kuhio(Hawaii's Territorial Rep. to U.S. Congress) is that its premise at the time was (1) to "save a dying race", (2) to accomplish this by taking away homesteading by everyone and allowing only Polynesian-Hawaiians to homestead, (3) putting them back on the land to farm. While the act has been amended since then, the original act of 1920 Sec. 207 clearly said: "The commission is authorized to lease to native Hawaiians the right to use and occupancy of a tract of Hawaiian homelands within the following acreage limits: (1) Not less than twenty nor more than eighty acres of agricultural lands; or (2) Not less than one hundred nor more than five hundred acres of first-class pastoral lands;

Comment: To be fair to Mr. Jenkins the Alaska State Constitution reads: "All income from the permanent fund shall be deposited in the general fund unless otherwise provided by law. [Amended 1976]. The clause "unless otherwise provided by law" was the amendment that allowed for the Statute that sets up the 50% payout from the Permanent Fund Earnings.  The other 50% of the Earnings has not been used to date to pay for government expenses.  So how can anyone argue that the Governor had to take half the dividend to pay for State expenses when they haven't been using half the funds that were already available ?  No, the People's half is not enshrined in the Constitution, but in the AK Constitution it does say that the Resources of this State shall be used for the Maximum Benefit of the People. (paraphrased)  This is the mandate that is fulfilled in the Permanent Fund Dividend.  And, no, it doesn't say that the Dividend can't be touched without a vote of the People, but if We the People are sharehold

Comment: Real life experience: I was attacked by a feral cat a relative regularly allowed into the house. While I was sitting, watching television, it leaped up, unprovoked, to bury its fangs deeply into my bare forearm resting on the arm of the chair. After cleaning and bandaging the bite wounds, the doctor at a nearby clinic gravely told me that I needed to get to an emergency room immediately. Signs of serious infection started appearing throughout the arm. The doctor at the emergency room said I was lucky that the membrane covering the bone in my forearm was not punctured. It took a lot of family pressure to get the relative to comply with quarantine procedures. Even six months later, the skin around the punctures showed redness and skin flaking.

Comment: I completely agree, but Mazda has a history of solo flying with things too long before others begin to lose interest. I have to admit that no-one was particularly interested in the rotary engine mostly because of its horrendous reputation in the early 70's but with an appropriate cash flush partner its explosive idiosyncrasies could have been ironed out; Ford would have been perfect at the time. The Miller Cycle was a legitimate entry into the interesting engine ledger despite not being particularly innovative, it was basically a slightly new approach to an old idea, but what a new approach! Had it been developed fully it would have been a power rich, reasonably fuel efficient, quiet and smooth powerplant with above average reliability and would have slotted beautifully into a more luxurious range, but Mazda kept it all to itself. Guess we'll have to wait and see whether they decide to share this time around or not, but unless they do then they'll always be the also-rans.

Comment: It's been 8 years since Billy left. What a respected drummer, even though he played backwards. Besides the R n R bands, he backed The Ink Spots, The 4 Aces & even Jimmy Soul (If you wanna be happy for the rest of your life. . .). No one was funnier. All of us wanted to be the butt of one of Billy's jokes. I was his doctor and once he showed up in my packed waiting room with no appt. My secretary, after checking our charts, said, "Mr. Hilton you haven't been here for some time. Why?" "I've been sick", he replied. The waiting room howled and insisted he be seen first.
Billy was good-looking and women chased him. I asked him what it was like with girls on the road. "It was scary. They would scream and pound and scratch at my hotel room door and at about 3 a.m. I'd let them out". That all ended when he met Stephanie. 
He faced his final diagnosis with a grin and a knowing twinkle in his eye. With tongue in cheek he sang My Way to BW. He died 2 days later. There was a bar at his funeral. A1

Comment: What a lovely painful article.  As someone who had a mother and a partner with dementia, and who has helped lead a support group for families, I can certainly relate.  So a couple of comments.  Never promise "I won't put you in.."  Instead promise - I will take care of you the very best I can.  Next be prepared that no nursing home will take as good care of your loved one as you could - they won't know about her food preferences, will not hear the voice tones that communicate so much, etc.  But in some ways they will be better.  Next, find and go to a support group.  Those who do say it's the most help they have; more than doctors, more than sometime distant families. Finally (tho there's so much more that can be said) in an a gift of grace, most caregivers will say that they are better people - more patient, more loving, less critical - because of what they've done.

Comment: I'm not talking about the "mere utterance" of racial slurs.   Obviously, if one is in one's home and speaking to friends and slinging racism, it's not illegal and it is protected.   Your neighbor overhearing you can't call the police and get you arrested for it.  That is a First Amendment right, true.

But, if you are out in public and doing the same thing, other factors will determine whether you have the same "right" to do what you are doing as someone in their own home.  I cannot stand on the street corner and shout anything I want and be protected by the First Amendment.  Hate speech, harassment, speech that incites violence or encourages violence, threats to others, slander, defamation, libel, and a few other categories of speech are not protected under the First Amendment.   It all depends on how, when, where, and to whom racial slurs are issued that will determine whether they are actually "free speech," unlike kneeling during the anthem.

Comment: I wish that bystanders who don't live on farms amongst working communities would not pass comment on issues that they are grossly ignorant about. Unfortunately most farmers are reluctant to speak up about the good that they are doing because there is likely a run down 'workers' house or two on their farm that outsiders could point fingers at. These houses are in the vast majority occupied by people who are not employed by the farmer and whom the farmer, in practise, has no ability to evict. Comment: Mountain bikes are not the devil or evil.  Nobody is saying that.  I have one, and love it.

Damage and degradation comes from wheel ruts on the trails due to bike weight and speed of the cyclists.  That's common sense.  Trails then become prone to losing more surface layer, with tree roots exposed, followed by increased erosion.  Further, e-bikes are becoming far more popular--thankfully--but it's very likely they will find there way into Wilderness areas making the problem worse, human nature being what it is, if this bill gets approved.

Wilderness is for quiet and solitude.

In other words, he pockets around $6,500/month in excessive per diem. He favors his legislative perk because he said he needs the extra money he "stacks up" in Juneau during the session to pay his bills when the legislature is not in session. He also said he uses some of his per diem money for a car tune-up in Juneau after he "drive(s) it to Juneau from Fairbanks" each year. 

Alaska state employees on business travel  are reimbursed for actual expenses and according to Peter Micciche his employer Connoco Phillips reimburses only actual expenses. The feds reimburse for actual expenses paid. I've taken lots of business trips and went TDY a fair amount. Never did my employers ever give me $6,000/month (or any amount) as "reimbursement" for expenses not incurred.

Comment: Thin plastic bags are an environmental disaster, but are a common product of the petrochemical industry, which has a part ownership in our "so-called president."

Not only do they kill marine life, but they blow everywhere, in transit to landfills and after deposition. I've seen Kansas highways marked by persistent trash on their north sides, with pasture lands miles north of the landfill carpeted with them.

When home, I carry a cooler to deposit refrigerated and frozen foods at the supermarket (and I've taken off the bar code so the checker doesn't charge me for it), and reusable canvas bags. However when I traveling or forgetful, I ask for paper bags.

In California, last month,  I asked for double paper bags in a desert supermarket, to keep those products cool while returning the home of friends. I was surprised, but pleased, because state or county ordinances require the markets to charge $.10 per paper bag (forty cents for two double-bags), but $.15 each for plastic ones.

Comment: The quote is part of a parable Jesus told to his disciples regarding the evil in humans, and is found in Luke 11:21-22:
"When a strong man armed keepeth his palace, his goods are in peace.

But when a (being? Beelzebub?) stronger than he shall come upon him, and overcome him, he taketh from him all his armour wherein he trusted, and divideth his spoils." (King James version)

Luke chapter 11 starts with teaching the Lord's prayer which we still speak today, and also the beautiful instruction "Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto thee."

In other words, be generous to your friends, don't let evil into your life or it will overcome you and destroy you.

This parable isn't about guns, which didn't exist 2000 years ago, it is about avoiding evil in our dealings with others, lest evil overcome us.

It makes perfect sense.

Comment: The Honolulu City Council recently passed a measure on second reading without objections that will increase the already horrendous traffic on the H-1 corridor during rush hour.  Bill 15 encourages transit-oriented development surrounding all of the rail stations, and will increase the populations in these areas.  It would have been fine if the bill restricted development to the stations in town.  However, the bill places no such limits, so development will surround the stations at Kapolei, Waipahu, and Pearl City.  No law can force those living in these new developments at the Ewa end of the rail line to take rail.  The practical reality is that many of them will take their cars to commute to work in town.

Comment: Algae in storage reservoirs is never eradicated. Rather it CAN be controlled by use of copper sulfate. In a reservoir like the one Wellington gets raw water from, using copper sulfate is frowned on because copper ion levels in trout bearing waters can destroy the "alevins" or newly hatched baby trout. Thus, even though there may be no breeding populations of trout, the EPA in all its glorious splendor prohibits using copper sulfate. The chemical in low concentrations is nontoxic to humans and livestock. Your daily vitamin supplement probably contains copper sulfate.

Comment: You're referring to chaos theory, developed by meteorologist Edward Lorenz about 40 years ago.  The core of his theory is that small changes in seemingly unrelated locations can have major consequences to future weather.  Yet he was able to model weather good enough to predict about 2 weeks in advance.  

It's not certain that chaos theory applies to climate change, but personally I believe that it does, and so, it appears do you.  According to your belief the impact of a small change in CO2 level can lead to major changes in future climate..  The burning of fossil fuels has led to a significant rise in atmospheric CO2..from about 280 ppm to about 400 ppm.  That's more than enough of a change to influence climate.

Comment: That was a good read.   It shows we have to careful to link a particular factor, (like owning shares or not owning shares), as having a causal effect on voting patterns.     I was surprised the preferences were as close as they were.   

Stock ownership is hardly an even playing field.   It's one thing to 'let it ride' in a retirement account hoping for modest retirement support.   It's quite another to have the extra income that gives you management/investment advice with the goal of creating wealth.   As in most things, wealth  increases your opportunites of success through mulitiple support structures, and this would include stock investment. 

I don't see any tax policy that changes that basic dynamic.   Government programs are hopefully designed to provide greater opportunity for those who would have very little otherwise.    It's why we've come to associate great wealth with 'privilage'.    Inequality of opportunity is a fact, not a statement of ideology.

Comment: You don't really understand what the source of American innovation is.

It has to do with money.

Since WWII, America has become the world's largest national economy. It achieved this through a combination of luck (not having had its infrastructure flattened, unlike most of Europe), government spending on infrastructure domestically, heavy investment in the military-industrial complex and a large population.

As a result, American-based companies thrived due to having large domestic markets and an aggressive US foreign policy that gained American companies access to foreign markets and resources on favourable terms.

As a result, American companies have been able to attract the best and brightest innovators in the world. The entertainment business is a good example. Comment: I know I should resist but every rooster likes to crow from his dungheap. As a farmer and engineer who has felt the loss of life in the tragedy of the runaway fire I think two things. As an aside also, SA is obviously not alone in suffering from thee uncontrolled bush or forest fires.  My thoughts: one, the fires were only indirectly related to the "drought", more to the ambient conditions at the time. There is also much more human interaction with flammable material in the area than ever before.  Humans flick out cigarette butts, light fires, live almost in the forest (some by choice, others seeking opportunity), need warmth, are careless (uneducated) and so on.

Second is that not too much seems to be being done about fire prevention and control. Aside from education, fire breaks are very limited and resources sparse. Commercial agriculture I am familiar with burns or cuts firebreaks every year and has (had) massive resources on standby during fire season.

Comment: The "study"--more like unsubstantiated conjecture--does not in any way "refute" the enormous quantity of science across a score of disciplines that show the validity of greenhouse theory.  John Tyndall's discovery of the green house effect in 1860 underpins entire fields of science. Without it, our understanding of atmospheric physic and chemistry, paleoclimate, paleontology and on and on lacks a foundation.  Without the greenhouse effect we have no idea how ice ages come and go. Surely you know this.

The reason we understand global warming now is because the mechanism of the greenhouse effect is so well understood in the paleoclimatic record of heating and cooling in the deep past. The difference now is one of degree, not kind. Human action is adding CO2 to the atmosphere at a rate NEVER BEFORE KNOWN in the entire existence of the planet.

Comment: @Keala Kaanui:  While that may be true, it's nowhere near the sophistication and flexibility that a true driverless platform would provide.  Sophistication comes from being able to efficiently bypass a stalled car or an accident with very little delay and being able to avoid accidents.  Can't do that with a train which by the way if there's ever an accident and it comes off the track, the train will be out of commission for days.  Flexibility refers to being able to autonomously drive directly from starting point to final destination with as little delay as possible while still allowing the occupant to make phone calls, work on their computer, or watch a movie.  Sure you can make phone calls, work on your computer, and watch a movie on Rail, but unless you live 200 yards from the Rail station and your destination is within 200 yards, you will have to make a transfer to a bus possibly before and after being in the Rail car which adds to commute times.  Rail will be obsolete in 10-20yrs.

Comment: This relates well to the discussion on election reform so I pose a question to commenters:

Do you really think that voters cast ballots for an individual because of genuine support for that individual or because that individual represents a certain political party?

It's my view that the majority of voters cast their ballots for parties rather than individuals come election time.  You could run a sack of marbles as a candidate representing any of the 3 leading parties and it could attract as many votes as a living human being if both were to represent that same party.

There are some commenters on electoral reform who insist we all vote for individuals to represent us in government however, I say to them that, in practise, the vast majority of votes end up being markers for political parties.  Electoral reform needs to be modeled on reality, not on theory.

Comment: Fast and Furious is a favorite hobbyhorse of the right that should be laid to rest. 

"About 2.2% of U.S. domestic arms sales between 2010 and 2012 were attributable to firearms trafficked across the U.S.-Mexico border. ... Comment: While the Hawaii GOP Chair may say for our Congressional delegation to "play nice" in the face of a Republican majority in both Congress and the White House, I think there is another way to look at this. We as the people of Hawaii should be looking at the skill set of our Congressional delegation to see if, really, they can work beyond the partisanship and actually get things passed, regardless. I cite, here, Senator Dan Inouye's overall skill set in being a deft Congressional leader no matter who was in charge of the Congress, or the White House. 
Our question as voters and residents of Hawaii is this: Is our current delegation able to rise and meet the challenge before it? Lets see if our Senators and Representatives are really worth the price we pay for electing them with this challenge. 
It is my hope that they square up, meet and beat the challenge. Because, regardless, we should expect the best our of our Congressional representatives in Washington.

Comment: I am not arguing whatsoever with this fund's returns. However I do have a question. 

How much of that balanced fund's returns came from a increase in the value of the fund's bond holdings (bond prices tend to rise as interest rates fall) during tha 15-yr average 7.68% return?  

And if one were to assume that from the pointof view of someone investing in that same fund today, that the returns would only be from the equity portion's capital appreciation (and hopefully not depreciation) and that the bond portion of the portfolio simply provided its interest rate return with no capital gains or losses (a fairly optimistic pointof view), based on the foregoing, what  rate of return, after costs, would you expect the Mawer Balanced Fund to produce over the next 10 to 15 years?  

Showing investor's this fund's past returns without considering the impossible to repeat interest rate decline but yet ignoring it in investment proposals to unsophisticated investors is at best, manipulative.

Comment: Look at this from a slightly different angle. but still thinking of educating and investing.

Seniors Now : 
My mother, did not touch a computer till she was 65. By 70 she had a grasp of email and cruzing the internet, but still uncomfortable with technology overall and could barely use her cell phone we got her.

Present Adults : 
My brother and I grew up with computers. we are both career IT people. but we did not start with computers till we were about 14 years old.

Kids : 
Most kids now don't need technology education, They get it because tech is all around them - like investing should be.  My brother's 5 year old daughter has her own computer, knows how to log into the server and get to her games. Comment: (Hoosier): ""The majority of land in Hawaii, on every island, is owned by a handful of trusts, corporations and LLCs (limited liability companies)." 
False. The State of Hawaii is the largest land owner. 
(Hoosier): "Raising the minimum wage in Hawaii from the existing $9.25 to at least $15 per hour and indexing that increase to the cost of living would be a major step."
Economic illiteracy. Here's a thought experiment. 
Proposal: In Hawaii, it shall be illegal to sell ___X___ (product) for less than ___$Y___ (price) per unit. 
1. Let X be "new televisions" and $Y be $500. Who gains? Who loses? Check below. 
Low end buyers ___ Low end sellers ___ High end buyers___ High end sellers ___
 2. Let X be "used cars" and $Y be $30,000. Who gains? Who loses?  Check below. 
Low end buyers ___ Low end sellers ___ High end buyers___ High end sellers ___
Repeat for commodities and above-market prices of your choice. 
In every case, low end sellers and low end buyers lose.

Comment: The problem with the government handling it, and I'm not sure I agree with your figures on overhead, is government dictates prices to providers rather than negotiating those prices, which tends to force providers out of the market. This ends up rationing care to those who cannot afford doctors who will not accept their insurance. This is the reason for the additional layer I mentioned, which currently does not exist. It would be regulated by the government, limiting their margins since they would not be taking risk and would require them to negotiate pricing with all providers so no matter who you choose as your provider your insurance will work. Since this would be done by a smaller number of companies they would have great bargaining power, but not monopolistic like the government behaves. Meanwhile, providers would not have to negotiate with countless insurers and vice versa, adding efficiency to the process. This is how most consumer distribution chains work, for good reason.

Comment: What is a real shame is there is no indication on the State's asphalt highway of any damage to the road. There are no ruts and the only potholes are few and located at the one busy intersection, Watson's Corner. The local State DOT crew occasionally shows up with some premix, and frankly, if THEY would do their job, I don't see anywhere else that needs much help (I used to work on an asphalt paving crew). The article should have shown pictures of the road, as there are the typical frost heaves, but the pavement is NOT broken nor are there potholes. 
The roads that need maintenance, as the City Manager stated, are the CITY roads, which are constantly graded and smoothed, which is a CITY cost, not State cost.

Comment: You are actually correct. The Supreme Court has ruled on this. Thompson v.Smith, 154 SE 579, 11 American Jurisprudence, Constitutional Law, section 329, page 1135 “The right of the Citizen to travel upon the public highways and to transport his property thereon, in the ordinary course of life and business, is a common right which he has under the right to enjoy life and liberty, to acquire and possess property, and to pursue happiness and safety. It includes the right, in so doing, to use the ordinary and usual conveyances of the day, and under the existing modes of travel, includes the right to drive a horse drawn carriage or wagon thereon or to operate an automobile thereon, for the usual and ordinary purpose of life and business.” –

There is no foundation for a government to require permission to drive, or for that matter enforce traffic violations that do not cause damage or injury.

Comment: Steve:  You present what I think is a key question regarding assistance to the homeless.  "Is the goal to make it "easier" to be homeless or is it to help individuals escape from homelessness?  Clearly directly giving to individuals only serves to make it just a little easier to be homeless....or for "professional beggers" (and, yes, eugene has some) to "make a living."  Donating to charitable organizations provides direct positive assistance....meals, some basic healthcare, clothing and temporary shelter....all helpful to the homeless.

However, IMO, it's the NEXT step which is most important: What can we do to help individuals escape from homelessness? How do we help some of them get jobs?  How do we help some of them deal with alcoholism, substance abuse and mental health issues?  How to we help the physically and mentally handicapped find long term appropriate support? How do we insure that vets returning with PTSD/brain injuries receive the support they need? (cont) Gary Crum

Comment: As an Alaskan physician, I wish to give an opposing view from Dr. Tomsen. She indicates women in rural areas rely on PP clinics for their healthcare and 75% of PP clinics are in underserved areas. How many and where are the PP clinics in AK? There are exactly 4, one each in Anchorage, Fairbanks, Juneau and Soldotna. Maybe Soldotna could be considered rural. The same women's healthcare minus abortion can be obtained in federally qualified Community Health Centers who also provide general medical care for all comers. And that is regardless of ability to pay. How many CHCs are in AK? 86 at last count on alaska.gov. The vast majority are in villages. I know as I have worked in many of them. To say women's healthcare will suffer if PP federal funding in ended is false and fear mongering. At worst PP will reduce the # of clinics. CHCs are increasing every year. PP is not just doing abortions but getting funds from body parts. I don't want my taxes contributing to that in any way.

Comment: Most of this column was quite good. However, the paragraphs referring to a "separation clause" in the First Amendment are misleading. The first part of the religion provisions in the First Amendment is the "establishment clause," prohibiting laws that create an "established" (i.e. official) religion, as in England and other countries. Court decisions such as those banning school prayer or nativity scenes on public property (if not accompanied by other symbols) are based on the reasoning that governmental support of these practices constitute establishment of religion.

The Constitution itself does not refer to separation of church and state, although Jefferson did in at least one letter.

I am not sure whether the distinction between "separation" and "establishment" makes a great deal of difference but think it is usually preferable to be precise.

Comment: Lela,

Gun control in most of Europe (as in US and the Euro colonies), is a modern invention, dating for the most part to post-WWI era when establishment fears of large numbers of armed and trained veterans, coinciding with rise of anarchism and Socialism (usually blamed on foreigners, usually subtly or not, eastern Euro Jews) as political threats to estab. order. Politicians made the same claims of increased crime rates and danger to society to disarm the law-abiding in what were already very low violence societies. England's first substantive restriction, for instance, was a licensing program enacted in 1920. Restrictions gradually increased to the confiscation of registered firearms and handgun bans of the '80s.

Comment: Right.  Looking Latino doesn't furnish probable cause for jack.  

Still, you've made an incorrect statement of the law.  Police don't need probable cause in order to stop a person and ask questions.  They need only "reasonable suspicion" --- not "probable cause" --- that the person has committed an offense.  Once a person is stopped on that ground, he can be detained briefly for questioning, and the questions can include the subject's identity and immigration status.  The policeman doesn't need to have a reasonable suspicion that the subject is here illegally in order to ask about immigration status.  In a case decided not too long ago, Justices Stevens, Souter, Ginsburg, and Breyer said that the 9th Circuit was wrong in holding that questioning of the subject about her immigration status was an independent violation of the Fourth Amendment.  Those Justices were certainly not alt-rightists.

Comment: I had a quick look at that survey. Statements are too long, they contain more than one idea and they are hard to understand. Either it was designed by people who had no idea how to do it or else, it was designed that way to bias the results.

Example: "It should always be clear which party is accountable for decisions made by government, even if this means that decisions are only made by one party." 

There are two different ideas conveyed by that statement. 

So if you answer Strongly Agree, what is it that you agree with? That a party should be accountable for decisions made by government? (sounds reasonable); or that it's all right to have decisions made by only one party? (which favors the status quo).

I would strongly support an independent, unbiased organization (if there is such a thing) to set up its own survey on that topic and to send the results to the government.

Comment: The "pros" continue to give terrible advice by focusing on tax rates rather than the absolute amount of tax paid. The goal is to minimize tax paid, not tax rates. This is extremely common.

Your TFSA should be packed with equities as these have the greatest return potential. Allowing equities to be taxed because of the dividend tax credit and 50% capital gains inclusion makes no sense at all. If you crunch the numbers, you'll pay more tax sheltering your interest bearing investments and allowing equities to be taxed. Why? Because interest bearing investments have very low returns. You should subject your lowest return investments to tax and shelter your highest return investments. That means bonds, GICs, etc in taxable accounts and 100% equities in your TFSA.

As far as the RRSP, it is untrue to say that withdrawals are subject to 100% taxation. A withdrawal could lead to no tax paid if the amount where small and there was no other income. It completely comes down to amounts and timing

Comment: Luckily everybody got a free pass on living another day. It may be an expensive learning curve for everyone. Hopefully a lesson will be learned. Planes are so important here and I always hate to see a good old one get damaged cause they do not build them like that anymore. Alaska is different. Anyone remember Ralph Marshall? He was an old guide back in the day. The FAA said he needed a full commercial license to fly clients on polar bear hunts. Even though he had no money, he fought them and eventually wound up at the Supreme court level and won. The SC made the FAA create the Alaska specific Part 91 license just for Alaska Guides. That license opened the door to many new pilots. Since then, the FAA has twice tried to get the license eliminated. They failed both times. The last time with a lot of help from the Alaska Professional Hunters Association. As fall hunting season approaches, please do not ask your pilot to fly over loaded or in bad weather. Live for another day. Thank you.

Comment: I'll agree with your assertion that a household firearm's primary purpose is to present a threat, but not that it is to actually kill. Statistics overwhelmingly indicate the primary purpose of a firearm is not to kill anyone, but rather to deter anyone from committing a criminal act against the firearm's owner. After all, only an infinitesimal fraction of a percent of the firearms in this country are ever used to kill anyone. Secondarily, they are used for recreational target shooting, which many consider fun.

By the way, California has begun confiscating all clips and magazines which hold over 10 rounds. These were purchased legally and at substantial expense by their owners, yet now they must sell them out of state, probably at a loss, or turn them in for destruction with no reimbursement, or face criminal charges. Anyone who claims firearm confiscation will never happen--I will never believe you. This is just the beginning.

Comment: Unfortunately it's not quite that simple.  There are lots of online calculators that will analyze rent vs. buy numbers for you:  http://www.getsmarteraboutmoney.ca/tools-and-calculators/buy-or-rent-calculator/buy-or-rent-calculator.aspx#.WLmEMG_ytpg 
If renting was always a waste of money, then everyone would buy a place no matter how high the cost, and that's clearly not a good idea.  There is always a breaking point beyond which house prices are high enough that it makes more financial sense to rent.  $2500 on rent might be a waste if it costs $2500 a month to buy the same place and one plans on staying there in the long term, but it's rare in today's market that the rental cost would be anywhere close to the total costs of ownership of an equivalent property.   According to the Economist, Canada has one of the highest price/rent ratios in the world, meaning that renting is comparatively cheap: economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/11/global-house-prices

Comment: This Moriarty states the oil industry is "not some cash cow". Excuse me, but neither is Alaska! Since the oil production is on AK land owned/possessed by the residents, tribes, and AK government as landlords, the oil companies shouldn't be asking for compensation for utilizing AK land/soil. Comment: A few reasons:
1) Herd Immunity (http://www.ovg.ox.ac.uk/herd-immunity)
2) Because failing to vaccinate leads to resurgences of things we had in check, like whooping cough, measles, and mumps (http://time.com/27308/4-diseases-making-a-comeback-thanks-to-anti-vaxxers/)
3) Because an unvaccinated 5-year-old doesn't only affect other 5-year-olds: they affect people in the population who can't be vaccinated (infants) or people with compromised immune systems (people with cancer). (http://www.cnn.com/2015/02/04/living/feat-measles-parents-vaccinate-children/)

Going unvaccinated isn't just a problem for that child. It's a problem for every other child, or anyone with a broken immune system, and society at large. You can choose to not vaccinate, but I don't think your child should be allowed to attend a public school without them. Freedom of choice stops when the choice is detrimental to everyone, and if you're not going to vaccinate, your child should not be around others.

Comment: I wonder if we are winning the battle against homelessness. 
There have been squatters (who would otherwise be homeless) living in the empty home next door to mine. Around 19 different people have stayed at 841 Hunt Circle during the past two years. I have notified the mayor and he's decided not to respond to my emails; I guess he figures they are at least out of sight. The neighbors are taking down license plate numbers because we think there are drug sales, "fencing" of stolen property, and theft from storage sheds in our neighborhood. 
Pete Petersen and Forrest Dunbar are the Assembly reps for this area and they, too, seem uninterested. When I saw Petersen at the post office he told me, "there is nothing I can do." I guess he figures it's OK to sell drugs, steal from neighbors, and "fence" property. 
One final note, the "senior squatter" (the first to move in but now lives elsewhere) shows up at the beginning of the month to collect rent from those living there. 
It's a big mess.

Comment: What's the "wow" for, Don417? Jeff's comment makes perfect sense. 
Owning my own business allowed me to do what I loved, to make my own decisions about what I did and how I did it. It allowed me to use my skills and hone them further. AND I took advantage of tax laws ("tax loopholes") that benefited me. BUT! No pension, no medical/dental coverage. No "employer" contributions to anything unless I ponied them up myself. I paid for sick day and vacation time--in fact, being sick penalized me further--couldn't sell anything!

One day, doing contract work for a BC govt. Ministry, talked to a BCGEU employee who was very nervous about impending strike action. She had it all figured out: union gave her this, she could do that and--If the strike didn't last too long--lose NO income while she was off work. I gave her my story about sick days, vacations; said if I stopped work--I stopped earning. The blank stare she gave me was priceless. She had absolutely no clue. 

But I never complained.

Comment: For the free market to reach equilibrium, there are 4 assumptions and 4 conditions you need to be true. If you're able to achieve all of those, then you get a free and fair market. However heathcare pretty much violates all of those assumptions. For example, you can't assume people will act rationally in the healthcare market, because they often face life and death situations. There's no perfect knowledge of the product/service they purchase, because you need at least 10 years of training to be a medical doctor. Costs don't say the same on volume - insurance is always cheaper with larger risk pools. Because you have violations on everything required for the free market, you need either a massive system of regulations, or you use something other than the free market. For further reading, look up Kenneth Arrow.

In the case of the pills I have been given the standard script of about 24 pills and always had most of them to return to the pharmacy.  There wasn't a big discussion of pain relief with Surgery just a standard script which I think might be part of our problem.

I understand everyone has a different tolerance for pain but why provide a weeks worth of pills when I am back to see the doctor in 2 days for a followup.  Also why is a narcotic the first line instead of a discussion about pain with the patient.

Comment: You are either unaware of or ignoring a significant fact.  A huge proportion of these plea deal situations are not an arrest and a single offense situation.  

Many of them are where a person commits a murder, an assault on someone else and a kidnapping on a third etc.  Many others are where a serial burglar gets arrested on 7 or 8 burglaries, car clouts, etc. and so there are numerous crimes with multiple victims.

Even if convicted on every single crime using police and judicial resources each and every time, the sentencing system will very seldom stack sentence on sentence on sentence.

Instead, the guy gets a longer sentence on one of his convictions and the others are served 'concurrently"  --- a waste of time and resources.  If the DA cuts a deal and the criminal gets that longer sentence without the numerous trials, that works for the system.

The alternative - trying everyone for everything means you have to at least quadruple the money you spend on prosecution.  Won't happen!

Comment: Mr. West noted, "In the years following the 1964 earthquake, Anchorage was a leader in safe building practices. It took the rest of the country decades to catch up. Today Anchorage keeps pace, but lags somewhat in the adoption of the latest building codes."

While it is true that Anchorage takes up to 3 years to adopt the latest building codes - we just adopted the 2012 IBC a few months ago and have not yet begun to assess the 2015 IBC - that may give an incorrect view of the structural engineering practice here.  In recent code cycles, most earthquake structural design approaches have been unchanged.  Code changes continually tinker around the edges, but major changes are quite rare.

More importantly, our building department does a more thorough review of structural design than most places in the country, including California, Oregon, and Washington.  As a result, structural design practice here is probably as up-to-date as just about any of the cities on the West Coast.

Comment: Except none of them are near the population centers or the logistics handling capacity needed.

Anchorage is the base of the railroad, with the railyard just off the port and its cargo handling capacity as well as routing for cargo laden trains. Further east are yards for any number of cargo companies including TOTE and Carlile Transport which move cargo throughout the south-central region (and further).
Relocating to Whittier, Valdez or Seward would require a massive realignment of logistics capacity. Additionally, with the limited redundancies of a single rail line/road (often co-located) in and out of those towns, an earthquake or even large avalanche (as we see frequently) could shut down vital supplies to and from the #1 and #2 population centers in the state for days. It would create a major issue for Anchorage and Mat-Su, never-mind further north communities like Fairbanks.

Comment: There's signpost ahead along the road to metabolic syndrome and it reads "Everything in moderation." 

It's a question-begging rationalization, which is why it's so popular. It's a perversion of the Greek adage meaning "nothing in excess." Even that is a vacuous tautology unless given operational criteria. 

Here's one: any eating pattern that has fasting insulin not returning during the day to a baseline seen in traditional populations has excess high-glycemic carbohydrates in their diet. The average person in Canada has fasting insulin well over double that, so typical "moderation" is very poor guidance indeed, except as the route to hyper-insulinemia, metabolic syndrome, type two diabetes, cardiovascular disease, Alzheimer's and most cancers, all of which have been increasing sharply in incidence over the past 30 years.

Grumpy? Hardly. Obnoxious? You bet. There are insulin-driven epidemics happening that threaten to bankrupt the healthcare system and economy. Silence is complicity.

Comment: Honestly, this Ambassador Lu may scupper any hope of a Canada-China trade agreement all on his own. I have been following his coverage and his message seems to be "Canada would be so lucky" to have improved relations with China. While this approach may work in some corners, it is a disaster here.
At this point in history, Canadians see themselves as safely ensconced at the heart of the developed world, with strong trade ties to the largest rich markets in the world. In spite of the NAFTA renegotiation there is no meaningful fear of trade isolation here. In order to be successful on trade the message must be "things are good, but we can make them better and we will all be wealthier". When Lu says Chinese are not interested in investing in Canada now, the response ranges from "who cares" to the major burn he gets in this article.
I suspect having been envoy to Australia, he was able to tap into a fear of trade isolation there, and is using the same playbook in Canada. It is a big error.

Comment: A wrongful dismissal suit usually happens a considerable time after the dismissal itself - so long that the facts are all known.  Issues of mitigation (how seriously you pursued finding a new job) come up at settlement or trial after the fact, so its a matter of evidence.

If a settlement is reached fairly quickly, it is almost always a lump sum payment, with no further need to mitigate.  I guess an employer can agree to make regular payments over the 'notice' period, but I've never heard of a continuing duty to look for work in that kind of deal.  The biggest problem here is that it seems to give the employer the unilateral right to decide if your efforts were reasonable.  That's horrible.

Statutory severance or pay in lieu of notice is not subject to mitigation at all (but the amounts are smaller.)

Comment: Unpressurized single engine IFR over mountains is way more risky than IFR down the kuskokwim.  Caravans are versatile, economical planes, but they flat-out suck for typical IFR flying. The right plane for that route would have been a pressurized twin, which has the performance to climb above the ice. The assumption many are making is they should have been IFR, and everything would have been fine.  The pilot was put in a difficult spot because market forces had him using the wrong tool for the job.  Still legal, but not smart. This is the hazard of the new "safety culture" which focuses on rule-following to a fault while ignoring old-fashioned risk management.  Nobody ever asks the pilots what they need to do their job more safely.   It's always top-down, with predictable results.

Comment: We worry about the northern ice cap melting. 

But it is happening at a much higher rate than expected. 

There's much more ice on the Antarctic continent. Scientists have drilled holes in the ice and in these core samples, have been able to trace these cycles of warmth and ice ages back to four hundred thousand years when all the ice disappeared from the South Pole. 

At that time sea levels rose about 400 ft. This is not the small cycles like we have seen 10 to 15 thousand years ago which affected the North Pole. 

Given that we have injected a horrendous amount of carbon dioxide in the last hundreds of years,  the fast rate of melting of the North Pole, and the appearance of cracks on the ice cap of the South Pole, it seems to me at least, that there's a higher risk that the South Pole ice will also be gone in 100 years. It may reappear in winter (for that pole) but all the ice will be gone by the summer.

Comment: The CURRENT Federal carbon tax on gasoline (10 cents/litre) is collected by the gas stations, as is the current Manitoba Provincial carbon tax on gasoline (14 cents/litre) and the GST (5%  on the total, after-tax price).

What is being proposed by Manitoba is another carbon tax, to be charged more broadly on many products and to be charged in addition to the current carbon tax on gasoline, will add another 5.8 cents in to the price of gasoline and should be collected by the gas station.  This is different from, for example, Ontario where the new carbon tax is buried in the price in order to increase complexity and reduce transparency.

I suppose the Federal government COULD add a 5th tax on gasoline in Manitoba.  It could be done either in an honest and transparent way, like Manitoba and B.C., or in a deceptive way, like in Ontario.  That would be up to the Federal government's discretion.

Comment: We can't even know if there was a Jesus of Nazareth. But if you subtract all the stuff that is similar to Pagan imagery, such as virgin birth, human sacrifice, anointing, resurrection, drinking blood, bridegroom, etc., then you are left with Jesus' message of love, forgiveness, repentance, and presumably his mistaken belief the world was about to end. I don't agree with the book 'Zealot' which has Jesus as an ordinary rebel in the civil strife of the times, with oppressed Jews fighting against Romans and their wealthy Jewish collaborators. Jesus seems more special than that. But it is important to know something of the mythology and the politics of the times to understand what may be factual in the New Testament. Jesus' message of a loving 'Abba' does not seem to be compatible with passages that make Jesus into a human sacrifice. And Vaticanism is not going to tell us much about Jesus with any accuracy.

Comment: Coming back to your earlier comment about profiteering. The "once off" investments get discounted over their lifetime (i.e. a portion of the cost gets charged to each item over the lifetime of the investment), like roads and hospitals and other item should. You extend their lifetime by maintaining them. That is another cost. You pay for the electricity for all those lights and air conditioners and refrigerators. You pay for the salaries of your staff. You allow for some theft. You allow for waste (although I think that the suppliers carry that to an extent). You rent the space for your store (if it is in a shopping centre). All these items add up. Comment: Larry, let's review how we got to this impasse. You complained that "years ago" there was "no public access" to CSP in Eagle River Valley. Then you mentioned a meeting at which you said park officials were "arrogant." You've never said when the meeting took place. I wasn't there. So how am I supposed to help you?

55 Ways to the Wilderness was written in 1972. My edition was revised in 1994, which is still 22 years ago (and it's still called 55 Ways…). Based on that, it seems likely there was public access up the South Fork in 1972. A park management plan published in 1980, but based on work beginning in 1977, also referred to numerous public access points in Eagle River Valley, including the one at the end of Hiland Road. Many of these trailheads needed parking areas or other amenities, but clearly they were being used in the late 1970s.

My point is that perhaps you misunderstood what the park officials were telling you. Or maybe they were just tired of your argumentative tone.

Comment: For people who don't know the cost and risk of doctors and other professionals, I would like to add few more words.

First is getting into the school. Students are required to be in top 10% of the University. Even with good grades some can be unlucky and not get accepted. Then you have a very useful Bachelor's Degree of Science.

When we go into the med school, study becomes more difficult.   After 4 year of med school we enter into residency which spans 3+ years. Those are 3+ years of even more stressful life and work with severely underpaid salary. 

After all these, we finally become a doctor. By this time, we have so much debt on our shoulder. Students nowadays graduate with debt between 150k to 500k or more. It's common to work 12+hrs to pay off our debt. Also, everything we do, we do it with our license on the line. Moreover, there are same risks associated opening up a clinic just like opening up any other businesses.

Comment: The above is an example of what you get when your understanding of the natural world comes from repeated 'Bambi'-viewings.  Nature is one hundreds of million year-long PARADE of extinction that stretches from before trilobites down to the present day.

Sustained eradication campaigns against feral cats are particularly effective on islands.  The Island Conservation and Ecology Group, Instituto de Ecologia del Universidad Autonoma de Mexico, Centro de Investigationes de Biologias de Noroeste and offices of the Areas Naturales Protegidas in 1994 helped local folks eradicate feral cats from 26 islands off the northwest Mexican coast. In five years they'd succeeded on 16 of them. Twenty-six endemic reptile, 21 endemic mammal and one endemic bird species recovered once the cats were gone.

For two other endemic birds it was too late — they're extinct.  I'd really, really hate it if we became the next species to become extinct because of overweening affection for a disease-ridden "pet".

Comment: It seems kind of strange that Wallonia, one region in Belgium, can stop a European Union trade deal. 

How then is Canada now supposed make trade deals with countries in the EU? 

Will Canada now have to wait for Britain to exit the EU before Canada can make a new trade deal with Britain?

If Canada can't get a trade deal with the EU, should Canada trade with any country in the EU? Should Canada let any country in EU sell products in Canada? 

Should Canada simply trade with the U.S.A.; Mexico; other countries in Central America; countries in South America; countries in Africa; Australia; New Zealand and countries in Asia?

If the EU won't trade with Canada, should Canada pull out of NATO and forget about helping to protect the EU?

Comment: oldgit_gittinolder, hard to believe you were a business owner for very long time because you'd understand how bad this proposed legislation is. Your righteous attitude about “…What they save by paying family members to do no work is made up by the rest of us….” suggests you don’t grasp the nuances of small businesses realities and tax law. When you, as a salaried employee, don’t pay the required pension contribution it takes to keep the system going, I, the business owner, have to pay twice – once as the employee and once as the employer. Twice+ again for employment insurance and a myriad of other services I never use. I also have tens of thousands worth of other expenses that you, as a salaried employee, don’t have and a risk profile that is very different than yours.  Now, the government wants to ignore these realities. Does that sound fair to you?
